title: Tipos de coment√°rio de linha (Line Comment Types)
body:
Issue Type: Feature Request The Visual Studio Code should identify which code snippet I'm trying to comment on, since anyone who does web development (html+php+js+css) sometimes has two (or more) language on the same line, but the type comment line of one does not work for the other. Example: if we have a type code: `

` the VSC only comments thus, regardless of where the cursor is: `` Ideal would be if he identified the code under the cursor and commented correctly: If the cursor is in the html code snippet `

` ==comment==>`` If the cursor is in the php code snippet `

` ==comment==> `

` Ps: The netbeans have managed to make that distinction, and this is very useful; Thankful. VS Code version: Code 1.25.1 (1dfc5e557209371715f655691b1235b6b26a06be, 2018-07-11T15:43:53.668Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299

title: [json] `json.format.enable = false` doesn't work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
If there were a way to at least change it to only validate upon save, I wouldn't have such a problem with it, but the real-time validation as I type is very distracting. It seems that out-of-the-box linting in general is inconsistent across languages with regards to how they're configured

### Steps to Reproduce

1. set `"json.format.enable": false` in settings
2. json files are still validated

### Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?

Yes

### Versions

v1.26.0-insider
macOS High Sierra v10.13.6

title: Improve messaging when running a task with no workspace
body:
When running the `Run Task` command from the menu, you are prompted with the following notification:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35271042/43861850-eef2f65e-9b0c-11e8-8e7a-b61a31cc386c.png)

For new users, they might not have a concept of a "workspace" or what a "task" is in the context of VS Code. We should add a link that points to our [Tasks docs](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks) for more information. 

Additionally, our docs should have an explanation of how tasks work with workspaces.

title: Better indicator for long extension installations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: If you are either on a slow connection or are installing a large extension, it's hard to identify if the installation is still proceeding or if it's stuck. There is the viewlet progress indicator, but that's not easy to identify with a specific extension as it's over the entire viewlet container. ### Current ### Suggestion Animate a `...` on the `Installing` text so that the progress is implicit. ![gif](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35271042/43855395-4c6677d8-9afa-11e8-91d6-466b83cd0d7a.gif)

body:
I would really like to have the option to place the find in file bar at the bottom like ATOM does it or have it more moveable across the editor. Sometimes it overlaps the code a little bit and the given padding on the top isn't very neat too.

How Atom does it: https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/images/find-replace-file.png

title: egrep like feature to subset display of lines based on regex  (i.e. hide code lines that don't match)
body:
The Mac console has a nice feature where any text file viewed can have only lines that match some search criteria displayed, however the feature is limited and doesn't support regex.

What would be great in VSCode would be a regex search feature allowing multiple combinations, e.g. xxx | yyy | zzz and then have an option to *only* show matching lines.

title: Breadcrumbs Option Bottom of Editor
body:
Issue Type: Settings Search Issue Please add the option to place breadcrumbs at the bottom of the editor. Coming from Intellij where the breadcrumbs are located closer towards the bottom, i'm having to retrain my eyes to look up. I often read from top to bottom, and constantly have to jump back to the top if I want to quickly glance at the breadcrumbs. Probably not a big deal for everyone, however I figured at least a position option would be nice to have. Thank you for this feature. title: Cursor color to distinguish between solitary cursors and groups of cursors
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
Searching didn't turn up any requests like this, or any means of accomplishing this.

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I am not talking about distinguishing between the "main" and additional cursors, such as in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22621, but rather single cursors and multiple cursors.

It would be very useful to know at a glance whether edits you make will _only_ affect the cursor you're currently looking at, or whether there are other cursors (potentially out of the viewable area of the editor) that will have changes made too.  Since _a_ cursor is almost always in the center of your focal area when you're looking at your editor and typing, it would make sense for every cursor to indicate visually whether it is solo or one of many, rather than for the indicator to be (for example) in the status bar, where it will generally be unnoticed.

I have on many occasions accidentally edited my code in multiple places because a previous change left multiple cursors hanging around.  In some cases I was interrupted from working and came to work without remembering about the multiple cursors.  In others it was the fact that VS Code has different rules about how long multiple cursors persist than the editor I used before it.  So (through years of using the other editor) I was accustomed to having the multiple cursors go away (for instance, after using an arrow key to move to another line) and through force of habit forgot that VS Code behaves differently in this regard.

A strong visual indicator--such as the color of the cursor, though it could be something else--would solve this problem.  Ideally it would be configurable.

- Log in as user rob, install global vscode, start it
- User rob gets an update
- Install fails, log says that code-insiders couldn't be killed. I assume it's trying to kill user xyz's instance

I don't know if that can be detected to be handled more gracefully or not, but in theory there shouldn't be a conflict right?

title: Double click + shift click should select all words in range
body:
On 1.25.1, with no extensions.

If I have text `Hello World`, and I do:

- Double click on `H`, so `Hello` is selected
- Shift-Click on `o`

In Word, Notepad, TextEdit, Chrome and many other apps: This would select over `Hello World`.

In Code, this selects `Hello Wo`.

title: Progress: allow to report progress on the taskbar
body:
Please add a Taskbar option to ProgressLocation to allow progress of tasks to be displayed in the Windows taskbar (or wherever appropriate in other OS/push to electron API to handle).

eg. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/shell/taskbar-extensions#progress-bars

title: Navigate by code-blocks with ctrl+arrow_up/down
body:
Ctrl + Arrow left/right is universally accepted by most text editors as the shortcut to move a cursor by one word. VSCode implements such behavior. 

Since VSCode also has knowledge about code blocks (i.e. collapsible blocks) I propose that this idea could be extended to horizontal navigation with Ctrl+ArrowUp going to a previous edge of a code block and Ctrl + ArrowDown to the next one.

I'd be willing to help with implementing such feature if someone could point me into the right direction.

- `Extension 'msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome' v4.8.1 is already installed, but a newer version 4.8.2 is available in the marketplace. Would you like to update? Yes(0) | No(1)`

title: Add support for predefined variable ${fileDirbasename}
body:
I would like to purpose an addition to the set of predefined variables that VS Code supports for `tasks.json` and `launch.json`.

Here's my use case.

- I have organized my code in modules, each module is just a folder with files.
- Some file names end with suffixes such as `_test.cc` or `_windows.cc`
- My build system relies on these conventions to generate build targets.

However, I have to be able to specify the surrounding context, i.e. module name without full path information, and I cannot do that, therefore this suggested change.

My current workaround looks like this, note the extra hackery for getting debugger launch to work (since I cannot launch the debugger through a batch script).

launch.json:

```json
{
  "name": "Debug (test)",
  "type": "cppvsdbg",
  "request": "launch",
  "program":
    "${workspaceFolder}/t2-output/win64-msvc-debug-default/temp_${fileBasenameNoExtension}.exe",
  "args": [],
  "stopAtEntry": false,
  "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
  "environment": [],
  "externalConsole": false,
  "preLaunchTask": "Build (test)"
}
```

tasks.json:

```json
{
  "label": "Build (test)",
  "type": "shell",
  "command": "build-test ${fileDirname} ${fileBasenameNoExtension}",
  "group": "build",
  "problemMatcher": [
    "$msCompile"
  ]
}
```

build-test.cmd:

```batch
set DIR_BASENAME=

for %%i in (%1) do (
  set DIR_BASENAME=%%~nxi
)

tundra2 "%DIR_BASENAME%_%2"

cd t2-output\win64-msvc-debug-default
del /q "temp_%2.exe" 2>NUL
copy "%DIR_BASENAME%_%2.exe" "temp_%2.exe"
```

The end result is that I can just hit F5 and go based on a single file that I'm working on but it would be nice if I could forgo all the intermediate steps and I think it could be useful for other people as well to be able to refer the surrounding directory name as a basename. My setup was inspired by conventions laid out in the Go project and since package names in Go work in a similar way to my module system I think it could be of use to people doing work in Go as well.

I know this is an incomplete pull request, in that it lacks tests and localized documentation for this new variable but I wanted to know if this was something we could add?

title: When renaming a symbol: "Overlapping ranges are not allowed!" (all extensions disabled)

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.25.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I have been getting this error showing up ~~intermittently, and though I can't predict when it will happen~~, it is guaranteed to happen after VS Code has been open for a while.

I have a multiroot workspace in which I'm working on a JavaScript project. I often use the "rename" feature, sometimes on a local symbol, and sometimes on an imported or exported symbol. The error has shown up in both cases. Note that the error _only_ happens when I try to rename something, and I can usually rename things for a while before the error first appears. Once it has appeared, it occurs every time until I restart VS Code. When the error shows up, the rename fails to execute, which means I can't ignore the error and rename anyway.

The error is "Overlapping ranges are not allowed!". The error has only been occurring in the last month or so, and I have systematically gone through, disabling extensions I've installed in that time, and extensions that interact with the editor.

~~I've run with extensions disabled, but because the error can take some time to show up, it's hard to draw conclusions from that. I've also been running in verbose mode in order to try and capture some data to report here.~~

~~At the very least, it'd be good to get some advice on how I can figure out which extensions were trying to get involved with whatever led to the error being thrown, because the stack trace doesn't highlight anything obvious to me, the output windows don't show any extension-specific errors or logs that seem relevant, and the process window doesn't show any nonstandard background extensions running either.~~

**Update:** I have ALL extensions currently disabled and I have found a point in my code where this error reliably occurs first time, every time. Unfortunately I can't seem to reproduce it with a simpler project setup. I have updated my various dependencies so that TypeScript 3.0.1 is everywhere, and have tried setting the current TypeScript version in VS Code to both 2.9.2 (VS Code's version) and 3.0.1 (workspace version). The error happens in both cases.

[renderer1.log seems relevant](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/2251151/renderer1.log) (shows error trace within)

[Here is the console trace log](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/2251089/trace.log)

[Here is a zip of the tsserver log](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/2251122/tsserver.zip) (Doesn't show any errors, so probably not an issue there, I guess?)

Stack trace screenshot:

![trace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/298883/43547930-0b2f0480-9620-11e8-9a81-cf755c095bd5.png)

Scopes screenshot pieced together from several screenshots while scrolling down:

![scope](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/298883/43547937-0fd3b170-9620-11e8-88a8-ab929b964eaf.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: YES

Any assistance would be greatly appreciated.

title: Slow when editing a file with very long lines

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Issue Type: Performance Issue ### Steps to reproduce 1. Open any text file with longer lines (more than 10k characters). 2. Try to edit the line (remove or add characters in between). ### Observations - The cursor movement is extremely slow and character updates take place after a long time. - The same behaviour is observed when Word Wrap is on. - Gives a warning sometimes > Tokenization is skipped for lines longer than 20k characters for performance reasons. ### System Information VS Code version: Code 1.25.1 (1dfc5e557209371715f655691b1235b6b26a06be, 2018-07-11T15:33:29.235Z) OS version: Darwin x64 17.7.0

title: Accessibility - Voiceover can not read messages in dialog boxes [macOS]

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.25.1
- OS Version: macOS High Siera 10.13.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press command + F5 to turn voiceover on.
2. Launch Visual Studio Code.
3. Press option + ctrl + m to go to the menu bar.
4. Navigate right using right arrow until you find "Code" menu item (it is the first one)
5. Use down arrow to expand the menu and press enter on "check for update" option.
If you are up to date, a dialog box saying that your version of VSCode is the latest should appear.

Expected result: We should be able to read the content of the dialog box using voiceover.

Actual result: Only sound is reproduced and no description is read by voiceover.

What I tried: I tried using VO keys (option + ctrl) and arrows to navigate within the dialog, but it only reads the content behind the dialog box.
I tried using tab key to navigate, but that option does not work too.

What I noticed while using VSCode:
Usually every dialog box that is displayed by VSCode is not accessible. The dialog box that asks whether I want to save the changes is partially accessible because I can use the tab key to navigate between "cancel", "save" and "don't save" buttons, but I am still not able to read the message.

Accessible dialog boxes: You can open the "About VSCode" dialog and see that voiceover is able to read everything within that dialog.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
Yes

title: Code detects repositories when used as a difftool in Git Bash

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Issue Type: Bug Steps to reproduce: ```shell $ git init $ touch 1 $ git add . $ git commit -m"foo" $ echo foo > 1 $ git difftool ``` The _git difftool_ command is defined as: ```shell code-insiders --wait --diff \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\" ``` When invoking `git difftool`, VS Code will correctly show one change for the repository, but will also show more than 5k changes in `$TEMP`, but there is no git repository at that location. ![screenshot1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24615132/43445387-848445d2-94a6-11e8-8186-71ff700aedd9.png) Why would VS Code load any source control provider here? There is also a message popping up: ![screenshot2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24615132/43445499-d3e582b2-94a6-11e8-912a-14e38bc6bd90.png) If I invoke the same command line manually, i. e. `code-insiders --wait --diff $TEMP/S9bziC_1 1`, the source control view behaves correctly, showing only one diff: ![screenshot3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24615132/43445737-6807282e-94a7-11e8-942f-b4211080b1cb.PNG) I noticed that in that case, VS code does not show a source control provider, but says 'SOURCE CONTROL: GIT'. Why does it make a difference whether `code-insiders --diff` is spawned from the git process vs. invoked by command line directly? VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.26.0-insider (64c433bf2bd43c85d1bfe5753bb6fb90ff4be14a, 2018-07-30T05:19:32.584Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063 git version 2.18.0.windows.1

title: Extension telemetry is not logged into log files when log level is changed to trace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
#54001 enabled extensions to log their telemetry to log files but only when VS Code is started from the cli with `--verbose` flag. The same should be allowed to do when VS Code is started normally and the log level is changed to `trace`.

For this we need the log level related api to be promoted form the proposed mode to stable which is planned for the August release
